Description.SourceString:
This switch allows mechanical or electrical <StyleBold>locking of the differential</>, effectively turning it into a spool. With a spool, both wheels on the axle rotate at the same speed, eliminating any speed difference.

This delivers traction and stability benefits when on-throttle, especially useful when a damaged or slipping wheel would otherwise drain engine torque. However, locking the differential causes significant understeer off-throttle and reduces steering responsiveness, making it harder to turn.

Because of these handling compromises, it should only be engaged in extreme conditions where maintaining traction is critical, such as severe wheel slip in rough rally terrain.
Description.LocalizedString:
This switch allows mechanical or electrical <StyleBold>locking of the differential</>, effectively turning it into a spool. With a spool, both wheels on the axle rotate at the same speed, eliminating any speed difference.

This delivers traction and stability benefits when on-throttle, especially useful when a damaged or slipping wheel would otherwise drain engine torque. However, locking the differential causes significant understeer off-throttle and reduces steering responsiveness, making it harder to turn.

Because of these handling compromises, it should only be engaged in extreme conditions where maintaining traction is critical, such as severe wheel slip in rough rally terrain.

Description.SourceString:
<StyleBold>Additional lights</> are powerful light components used to improve visibility during night stages and low visibility conditions in rally racing. While they can significantly enhance a driver's ability to see the road ahead, many cars only have them as optional equipment, and regulations often enforce their installation for night events.

These lights are delicate and positioned on the cars front, making them vulnerable to damage from collisions. Because of their fragility, installing additional lights requires the cars bodywork to be in good condition. <StyleBold>If the front bodywork is heavily damaged, it must be repaired</> before the lights can be securely fitted, ensuring both safety and functionality.
Description.LocalizedString:

Because of their fragility, installing additional lights requires the cars bodywork to be in good condition. <StyleBold>If the front bodywork is heavily damaged, it must be repaired</> before the lights can be securely fitted, ensuring both safety and functionality.

Description.SourceString:
<StyleBold>Higher gear ratios</> in a car are designed to improve acceleration, allowing the vehicle to reach top speeds more quickly from a standstill. By favoring quicker engine revving and faster power delivery, these ratios provide an advantage during rapid changes in pace, such as tight corners or technical sections.

However, this comes with trade-offs. While acceleration is enhanced, the cars top speed is reduced, limiting its maximum velocity on straights. Moreover, higher ratios can negatively affect traction, as increased torque at the wheels may lead to wheel spin, especially on loose or slippery surfaces.
Description.LocalizedString:
<StyleBold>Higher gear ratios</> in a car are designed to improve acceleration, allowing the vehicle to reach top speeds more quickly from a standstill. By favoring quicker engine revving and faster power delivery, these ratios provide an advantage during rapid changes in pace, such as tight corners or technical sections.

However, this comes with trade-offs. While acceleration is enhanced, the cars top speed is reduced, limiting its maximum velocity on straights. Moreover, higher ratios can negatively affect traction, as increased torque at the wheels may lead to wheel spin, especially on loose or slippery surfaces.

Description.SourceString:
In a rally car, adjusting the <StyleBold>torque ratio sent to the front differential</> allows control over front torque distribution.

Setting this ratio higher than the rear shifts torque bias to the front, improving traction but also increasing the overall final drive ratio.
This change can reduce the top speed while enhancing acceleration.
To balance this, you can adjust the gearbox final ratio in the opposite direction to maintain desired overall gearing.

An asymmetric setup also preloads the center differential by introducing a small slip between front and rear outputs, enabling quicker response to axle slip and improving handling and stability on varied surfaces.
Description.LocalizedString:
In a rally car, adjusting the <StyleBold>torque ratio sent to the front differential</> allows control over front torque distribution.

Setting this ratio higher than the rear shifts torque bias to the front, improving traction but also increasing the overall final drive ratio.
This change can reduce the top speed while enhancing acceleration.
To balance this, you can adjust the gearbox final ratio in the opposite direction to maintain desired overall gearing.

An asymmetric setup also preloads the center differential by introducing a small slip between front and rear outputs, enabling quicker response to axle slip and improving handling and stability on varied surfaces.

Description.SourceString:
<StyleBold>Each gearset</> consists of a pair of gearbox shafts (and, if available, a drop gear) equipped with fixed gears.

When selecting the ideal gearset for a rally stage, consider that closer lower ratios can provide better acceleration on high-traction surfaces, while wider lower ratios may be preferable on loose or slippery terrain to increase wheel torque and maintain control.

Increasing the gear set value selects wider lower ratios.
Decreasing the value selects closer lower ratios.

Choose the configuration that best matches the stage conditions to optimize performance.
<StyleBold>Different Gear set may have a different number of Gears.</>

Description.SourceString:
Modulating brake power becomes more difficult on low-grip surfaces, so choosing smaller brake discs can help by directly reducing the brake torque applied.

Brake discs are sorted by diameter and cooling efficiency, the larger the disc, the greater the potential brake torque and better cooling.

Smaller, non-vented discs tend to heat up more quickly than larger, highly vented ones, which is important to consider in your strategy.

Keep in mind that changing the discs will likely affect your brake bias as well.
Description.LocalizedString:
Modulating brake power becomes more difficult on low-grip surfaces, so choosing smaller brake discs can help by directly reducing the brake torque applied.

Brake discs are sorted by diameter and cooling efficiency, the larger the disc, the greater the potential brake torque and better cooling.

Smaller, non-vented discs tend to heat up more quickly than larger, highly vented ones, which is important to consider in your strategy.

Keep in mind that changing the discs will likely affect your brake bias as well.

Description.SourceString:
If a disc is compatible with multiple <StyleBold>calipers</>, youll see the available options sorted by piston area size. 

A larger piston area generally means greater braking force and better cooling efficiency. 

However, keep in mind that each caliper uses its own set of brake pad compounds, so the actual wheel torque may vary depending on the caliper chosen.
Description.LocalizedString:
If a disc is compatible with multiple <StyleBold>calipers</>, youll see the available options sorted by piston area size. 

A larger piston area generally means greater braking force and better cooling efficiency. 

However, keep in mind that each caliper uses its own set of brake pad compounds, so the actual wheel torque may vary depending on the caliper chosen.

Description.SourceString:
You can select from various compounds for your <StyleBold>brake pads or shoes</>, each suited to different driving conditions.

For <StyleBold>shorter</> rally stages, you might prefer softer pads with a strong initial bite and better stopping power. This does come at a cost though, with faster wear and increased chance of locking on loose surfaces.
For <StyleBold>longer</> or low-grip stages, more highly durable compounds are generally better, as they last longer and maintain a more consistent performance.

Keep in mind that different pads or shoes can affect the brake bias at each wheel, so always check and adjust the bias accordingly to ensure optimal handling and safety.
Description.LocalizedString:
You can select from various compounds for your <StyleBold>brake pads or shoes</>, each suited to different driving conditions.

For <StyleBold>shorter</> rally stages, you might prefer softer pads with a strong initial bite and better stopping power. This does come at a cost though, with faster wear and increased chance of locking on loose surfaces.
For <StyleBold>longer</> or low-grip stages, more highly durable compounds are generally better, as they last longer and maintain a more consistent performance.

Keep in mind that different pads or shoes can affect the brake bias at each wheel, so always check and adjust the bias accordingly to ensure optimal handling and safety.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>Master Cylinder</> converts the drivers foot force into hydraulic pressure for the braking system.

In rally cars, it can come as a single unit with two internal cylinders for the front and rear axles. This design limits direct adjustment of brake bias, but bias can be indirectly influenced by altering the diameters of these cylinders.

Alternatively, some setups use two separate Master Cylinders, one for each axle. This allows for direct brake bias control through a lever mechanism, which adjusts how much the brake pedal pushes on each cylinder, giving the driver fine-tuned <StyleBold>braking balance between</> front and rear wheels.

Increasing the Master Cylinders value will reduce the line pressure, decreasing braking power, making it harder to lock by requiring heavier braking inputs. This is ideal for more loose or low grip surface. Decreasing the Master Cylinder will increase the line pressure, increasing braking power to the point that the brakes lock, which is better suited for higher grip tarmac stages.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>TorSen differential</> in a rally car doesnt lock the two output shafts (axles or wheels) together on throttle or coasting unless theres a difference in torque at the wheels. When torque difference occurs, it transfers some power from the spinning axle to the one with better traction, improving grip compared to a standard open differential.

This ability depends on the <StyleBold>Torque Bias Ratio (TBR)</>, which defines the torque multiplication between wheels. If one wheel has zero torque, no transfer occurs, and the vehicle can get stuck.

Increasing TBR will add more locking effect at the wheels, improving traction on more loose surfaces when on throttle and adding stability off throttle. Too much locking effect though, can create more understeer in situations where there are higher grip levels.

Unlike LSDs, TorSen offers smooth operation without friction plates, reducing wear.
Description.LocalizedString:
The <StyleBold>TorSen differential</> in a rally car doesnt lock the two output shafts (axles or wheels) together on throttle or coasting unless theres a difference in torque at the wheels. When torque difference occurs, it transfers some power from the spinning axle to the one with better traction, improving grip compared to a standard open differential.

This ability depends on the <StyleBold>Torque Bias Ratio (TBR)</>, which defines the torque multiplication between wheels. If one wheel has zero torque, no transfer occurs, and the vehicle can get stuck.

Increasing TBR will add more locking effect at the wheels, improving traction on more loose surfaces when on throttle and adding stability off throttle. Too much locking effect though, can create more understeer in situations where there are higher grip levels.

Unlike LSDs, TorSen offers smooth operation without friction plates, reducing wear.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>Ramp Angle</> of a <StyleBold>Limited Slip Differential (LSD)</> controls how much input torque clamps the two output shafts together. The Power side angle (left value) affects clamping under acceleration, while the Coast side angle (right value) affects it under deceleration.

<StyleBold>Lower angles</> increase clamping force and traction but reduce speed difference and steering agility.
<StyleBold>Higher angles</> improve steering but allow more slippage or less stability. The Locking Effect (LE) shows the percentage of torque clamping the shafts, higher LE means stronger lock. Front LSDs typically have higher angles for better steering.

Remember that brakes dont influence Coast side locking since LSD responds to engine torque.
Description.LocalizedString:
The <StyleBold>Ramp Angle</> of a <StyleBold>Limited Slip Differential (LSD)</> controls how much input torque clamps the two output shafts together. The Power side angle (left value) affects clamping under acceleration, while the Coast side angle (right value) affects it under deceleration.

<StyleBold>Lower angles</> increase clamping force and traction but reduce speed difference and steering agility.
<StyleBold>Higher angles</> improve steering but allow more slippage or less stability. The Locking Effect (LE) shows the percentage of torque clamping the shafts, higher LE means stronger lock. Front LSDs typically have higher angles for better steering.

Remember that brakes dont influence Coast side locking since LSD responds to engine torque.

Description.SourceString:
You can adjust the <StyleBold>torque distribution to the rear differential</> by altering its ratio relative to the front differential.

Setting a higher ratio than the front shifts more torque to the rear, increasing rear bias.
However, this also raises the overall final drive ratio, which reduces top speed but improves acceleration.
To maintain the original final drive ratio, you can compensate by adjusting the gearbox final ratio in the opposite direction.

This asymmetric setup not only changes the front-to-rear torque balance but can also preload the center differential, allowing it to respond quicker to differences in axle slip, enhancing traction and handling in rally conditions.
Description.LocalizedString:
You can adjust the <StyleBold>torque distribution to the rear differential</> by altering its ratio relative to the front differential.

Setting a higher ratio than the front shifts more torque to the rear, increasing rear bias.
However, this also raises the overall final drive ratio, which reduces top speed but improves acceleration.
To maintain the original final drive ratio, you can compensate by adjusting the gearbox final ratio in the opposite direction.

This asymmetric setup not only changes the front-to-rear torque balance but can also preload the center differential, allowing it to respond quicker to differences in axle slip, enhancing traction and handling in rally conditions.

However, this comes with trade-offs. While acceleration is enhanced, the cars top speed is reduced, limiting its maximum velocity on straights. Moreover, higher ratios can negatively affect traction, as increased torque at the wheels may lead to wheel spin, especially on loose or slippery surfaces.

Description.SourceString:
You may adjust one or both <StyleBold>axle differential ratios</>; even differently one from the other. Setting a higher ratio at the front shifts more torque to the front wheels, enhancing front torque bias and viceversa.

However, this also raises the overall final drive ratio, which reduces top speed but improves acceleration. To maintain the original final drive effect, you can compensate by adjusting the gearbox final ratio in the opposite direction.

This asymmetric setup not only changes torque distribution but also preloads the center differential, allowing it to respond more quickly to differences in wheel slip between axles, improving traction and handling in rally conditions.

Description.SourceString:
In a car equipped with <StyleBold>two master cylinders</>, the brake pressure distribution can be adjusted by manipulating a lever that controls the <StyleBold>pressure bias ratio between the front and rear brakes</>. 

This system allows for fine-tuning the braking performance based on driving conditions and surface grip.

Shifting the Brake Bias forwards can make the car behave more predictably, biasing the car towards understeer during braking. Shifting the bias rewards will allow for more rotation and oversteer during braking, but can make the car more difficult to control. 
Find the right balance for your own driving preference and surface type youre driving on.

Its important to note that this pressure bias setting does not directly translate to the final brake torque at each wheel. Variations such as brake caliper efficiency, brake disc size, and tyre grip can all influence the actual torque applied. Therefore, always verify the final brake torque distribution on the wheels to ensure optimal balance and performance.
Description.LocalizedString:
In a car equipped with <StyleBold>two master cylinders</>, the brake pressure distribution can be adjusted by manipulating a lever that controls the <StyleBold>pressure bias ratio between the front and rear brakes</>. 

This system allows for fine-tuning the braking performance based on driving conditions and surface grip.

Shifting the Brake Bias forwards can make the car behave more predictably, biasing the car towards understeer during braking. Shifting the bias rewards will allow for more rotation and oversteer during braking, but can make the car more difficult to control. 
Find the right balance for your own driving preference and surface type youre driving on.

Its important to note that this pressure bias setting does not directly translate to the final brake torque at each wheel. Variations such as brake caliper efficiency, brake disc size, and tyre grip can all influence the actual torque applied. Therefore, always verify the final brake torque distribution on the wheels to ensure optimal balance and performance.

Description.SourceString:
When viewed from the front, wheels have <StyleBold>negative camber</> if the tops of the tyre tilt inward toward the centre of the car, and <StyleBold>positive camber</> if they tilt outward.

<StyleBold>Negative camber</> improves grip and tyre responsiveness , allowing the outer wheel during a corner mantain a better tyre contact patch.

However, too much negative camber reduces the contact patch on straights and concentrates stress on the inner edge, which can decrease acceleration and braking performance. It can also lead to situations, especially when the car is stiffer and has less roll, where the full width of the tyre isnt used in a corner leading to a reduction in peak cornering grip.

It's important to monitor tyre temperatures, ensuring the difference between the inner and outer edges doesnt exceed <StyleBold>20C</> to maintain balanced grip and tyre life.
Description.LocalizedString:
When viewed from the front, wheels have <StyleBold>negative camber</> if the tops of the tyre tilt inward toward the centre of the car, and <StyleBold>positive camber</> if they tilt outward.

<StyleBold>Negative camber</> improves grip and tyre responsiveness , allowing the outer wheel during a corner mantain a better tyre contact patch.

However, too much negative camber reduces the contact patch on straights and concentrates stress on the inner edge, which can decrease acceleration and braking performance. It can also lead to situations, especially when the car is stiffer and has less roll, where the full width of the tyre isnt used in a corner leading to a reduction in peak cornering grip.

It's important to monitor tyre temperatures, ensuring the difference between the inner and outer edges doesnt exceed <StyleBold>20C</> to maintain balanced grip and tyre life.

Description.SourceString:
Basic or stock brake systems typically offer limited adjustability, but they can include an adjustable <StyleBold>Proportioning Valve</> to enhance brake balance. As the car decelerates, it requires increasing front brake bias for stability and control. 
The Proportioning Valve achieves this by <StyleBold>reducing the rear brake line pressure</> once a certain Preload pressure is reached. This reduction occurs according to a set Ratio, allowing fine-tuning of brake performance. 

Adjusting the ratio changes how much pressure is cut from the rear brakes: <StyleBold>higher ratios</> decrease the pressure reduction, making the rear brakes more aggressive, while <StyleBold>lower ratios</> increase pressure reduction for a more stable rear braking feel.
Description.LocalizedString:
Basic or stock brake systems typically offer limited adjustability, but they can include an adjustable <StyleBold>Proportioning Valve</> to enhance brake balance. As the car decelerates, it requires increasing front brake bias for stability and control. 
The Proportioning Valve achieves this by <StyleBold>reducing the rear brake line pressure</> once a certain Preload pressure is reached. This reduction occurs according to a set Ratio, allowing fine-tuning of brake performance. 

Adjusting the ratio changes how much pressure is cut from the rear brakes: <StyleBold>higher ratios</> decrease the pressure reduction, making the rear brakes more aggressive, while <StyleBold>lower ratios</> increase pressure reduction for a more stable rear braking feel.

Description.SourceString:
Basic or stock brake systems typically offer limited adjustability, but they often include an adjustable <StyleBold>Proportioning Valve</> to enhance brake balance. As the car decelerates, it requires increasing front brake bias for stability and control. 
The Proportioning Valve achieves this by <StyleBold>reducing the rear brake line pressure</> once a certain Preload pressure is reached. This reduction occurs according to a set Ratio, allowing fine-tuning of brake performance. 

Adjusting the Preload pressure changes the point of the rear pressure cut. A <StyleBold>higher Preload</> delays the cut, making rear braking more aggressive, while a <StyleBold>lower Preload</> causes earlier cut, favoring front brake dominance.

The Proportioning Valve achieves this by <StyleBold>reducing the rear brake line pressure</> once a certain Preload pressure is reached. This reduction occurs according to a set Ratio, allowing fine-tuning of brake performance. 

Adjusting the Preload pressure changes the point of the rear pressure cut. A <StyleBold>higher Preload</> delays the cut, making rear braking more aggressive, while a <StyleBold>lower Preload</> causes earlier cut, favoring front brake dominance.

Description.SourceString:
<StyleBold>Slow bump</> damping controls the low-speed resistance of the damper shaft during suspension compression, in response to driver inputs.

Increasing slow bump damping strengthens the force opposing wheel bump, helping to slow down body movements for better control.

However, too high a setting can make the car feel less responsive to input, slowing the rate at which tyres load up in grip. It can also cause a pumping effect, where the suspension appears underdamped but is actually overdamped, relying mainly on tyre sidewall flex with minimal damping.
Typically, bump damping is set lower than rebound damping since the spring also resists compression. In softer springs, slightly higher bump damping can help reduce load transfer.
Description.LocalizedString:
<StyleBold>Slow bump</> damping controls the low-speed resistance of the damper shaft during suspension compression, in response to driver inputs.

Increasing slow bump damping strengthens the force opposing wheel bump, helping to slow down body movements for better control.

However, too high a setting can make the car feel less responsive to input, slowing the rate at which tyres load up in grip. It can also cause a pumping effect, where the suspension appears underdamped but is actually overdamped, relying mainly on tyre sidewall flex with minimal damping.
Typically, bump damping is set lower than rebound damping since the spring also resists compression. In softer springs, slightly higher bump damping can help reduce load transfer.

Description.SourceString:
<StyleBold>Slow rebound</> damping regulates the low-speed resistance of the damper shaft against the wheels downward movement, extension, or droop, caused by driver inputs.

Increasing this setting raises the force opposing suspension extension, which helps control body movements by slowing them down, resulting in improved stability and handling.

However, higher slow rebound damping can also prevent the suspension from extending quickly enough to maintain tyre grip in response to driver input.
Description.LocalizedString:
<StyleBold>Slow rebound</> damping regulates the low-speed resistance of the damper shaft against the wheels downward movement, extension, or droop, caused by driver inputs.

Increasing this setting raises the force opposing suspension extension, which helps control body movements by slowing them down, resulting in improved stability and handling.

However, higher slow rebound damping can also prevent the suspension from extending quickly enough to maintain tyre grip in response to driver input.

Description.SourceString:
<StyleBold>Fast bump</> damping controls the resistance force on the damper shaft during rapid suspension compression, in repsonse to suspension movement caused by the terrain.

Increasing this setting slows down the suspensions compression by adding more resistance, reducing oscillations and improving control. 

However, too high a fast bump setting can cause a pumping effect, where the suspension feels underdamped despite being overdamped, resulting in most compression being absorbed by the tyre sidewall, which offers minimal damping. It can also amplify the feeling of larger bumps on rougher terrain, by not allowing the suspension to compress quickly enough to absorb the impact.
Typically, bump damping is set lower than rebound damping because the spring force also opposes compression.
Description.LocalizedString:
<StyleBold>Fast bump</> damping controls the resistance force on the damper shaft during rapid suspension compression, in repsonse to suspension movement caused by the terrain.

Increasing this setting slows down the suspensions compression by adding more resistance, reducing oscillations and improving control. 

However, too high a fast bump setting can cause a pumping effect, where the suspension feels underdamped despite being overdamped, resulting in most compression being absorbed by the tyre sidewall, which offers minimal damping. It can also amplify the feeling of larger bumps on rougher terrain, by not allowing the suspension to compress quickly enough to absorb the impact.
Typically, bump damping is set lower than rebound damping because the spring force also opposes compression.

Description.SourceString:
<StyleBold>Fast rebound</> damping controls the high-speed resistance of the damper shaft during extension and wheel droop, in response to suspension movement caused by the terrain.

Increasing this setting raises the force opposing suspension extension, which helps to slow down and better control wheel oscillations. This creates a firmer response, improving stability on smoother terrain, but can in turn reduce the wheel's contact time with the ground, potentially impacting grip on rougher surfaces.
Description.LocalizedString:
<StyleBold>Fast rebound</> damping controls the high-speed resistance of the damper shaft during extension and wheel droop, in response to suspension movement caused by the terrain.

Increasing this setting raises the force opposing suspension extension, which helps to slow down and better control wheel oscillations. This creates a firmer response, improving stability on smoother terrain, but can in turn reduce the wheel's contact time with the ground, potentially impacting grip on rougher surfaces.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>Bump Threshold Speed</> in a car's suspension is adjusted using the Fast Bump preload via a simple screw. This adjustment controls when the piston holes fully open, transitioning the damper to its softer setting.

Increasing the Bump Transition delays the opening, making the suspension maintain higher damping during rapid vibrations, improving stability but potentially increasing tyre contact losses.

Decreasing the Bump Transition value allows the opening to free up sooner, causing the softer damping phase to activate sooner, reducing the force applied during normal body movements.
While this can enhance comfort, it may also lead to unwanted vehicle oscillations, affecting overall handling and control.
Description.LocalizedString:
The <StyleBold>Bump Threshold Speed</> in a car's suspension is adjusted using the Fast Bump preload via a simple screw. This adjustment controls when the piston holes fully open, transitioning the damper to its softer setting.

Increasing the Bump Transition delays the opening, making the suspension maintain higher damping during rapid vibrations, improving stability but potentially increasing tyre contact losses.

Decreasing the Bump Transition value allows the opening to free up sooner, causing the softer damping phase to activate sooner, reducing the force applied during normal body movements.
While this can enhance comfort, it may also lead to unwanted vehicle oscillations, affecting overall handling and control.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>Rebound Transition</> in a car suspension is adjusted using the Fast Rebound preload, controlled by a simple screw.

This mechanism either anticipates or delays the full opening of the piston holes, which sets the damper to its soft rebound rate.

Increasing the Rebound Transition value will delay the opening, maintaining higher damping during fast vibrations, improving stability but potentially increasing tyre contact losses.

Lowering the Rebound Transition value will anticipate the opening, reducing damping force earlier during rebound, which can lead to less control over body movements through unwanted oscillations, but is better suited to rougher and bumpier surfaces.
Description.LocalizedString:
The <StyleBold>Rebound Transition</> in a car suspension is adjusted using the Fast Rebound preload, controlled by a simple screw.

This mechanism either anticipates or delays the full opening of the piston holes, which sets the damper to its soft rebound rate.

Increasing the Rebound Transition value will delay the opening, maintaining higher damping during fast vibrations, improving stability but potentially increasing tyre contact losses.

Lowering the Rebound Transition value will anticipate the opening, reducing damping force earlier during rebound, which can lead to less control over body movements through unwanted oscillations, but is better suited to rougher and bumpier surfaces.

Description.SourceString:
In the top-down/birds-eye view, car wheels are <StyleBold>Toe In</> if angled inward towards the centre of the car and <StyleBold>Toe Out</> if angled outward.

<StyleBold>Front Toe In</> boosts straight-line stability by keeping the car steady, while <StyleBold>Front Toe Out</> reduces Camber Thrust effects, sharpening turn-in and responsiveness of the car. 
 
<StyleBold>Rear Toe In</> enhances cornering stability by creating lateral force and improving grip, whereas <StyleBold>Rear Toe Out</> reduces stability, allowing more rotation leading to an increase in oversteer 

Rally setups often use slight Front Toe Out for better responsiveness and Rear Toe In for balanced cornering stability. Toe settings balance stability and agility based on driving needs.
Description.LocalizedString:
In the top-down/birds-eye view, car wheels are <StyleBold>Toe In</> if angled inward towards the centre of the car and <StyleBold>Toe Out</> if angled outward.

<StyleBold>Front Toe In</> boosts straight-line stability by keeping the car steady, while <StyleBold>Front Toe Out</> reduces Camber Thrust effects, sharpening turn-in and responsiveness of the car. 
 
<StyleBold>Rear Toe In</> enhances cornering stability by creating lateral force and improving grip, whereas <StyleBold>Rear Toe Out</> reduces stability, allowing more rotation leading to an increase in oversteer 

Rally setups often use slight Front Toe Out for better responsiveness and Rear Toe In for balanced cornering stability. Toe settings balance stability and agility based on driving needs.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>ride height</> is adjusted using an adjuster ring that shifts the spring perch up or down, raising or lowering the car. Changing the spring seat alters the chassis height and static corner weights, but it also affects the dampers working point.

Increasing the Adjuster Ring value will raise the ride height of the car up, helping to prevent the car from bottoming out but can make the car feel softer and less responsive in turns. Decreasing the value will drop the ride height, making the cars handling feel more responsive to driver inputs, but increasing the chance of bottoming out on rougher terrain. 

After changing ride height you must check damper travel and spring compression to ensure theres still sufficient bump and rebound range and no bottoming or topping out.
Re-verify bump stops, ride frequency and alignment settings, and make further adjustments to spring preload or damping as needed so the suspension operates safely and effectively across rally terrain.
Description.LocalizedString:
The <StyleBold>ride height</> is adjusted using an adjuster ring that shifts the spring perch up or down, raising or lowering the car. Changing the spring seat alters the chassis height and static corner weights, but it also affects the dampers working point.

Increasing the Adjuster Ring value will raise the ride height of the car up, helping to prevent the car from bottoming out but can make the car feel softer and less responsive in turns. Decreasing the value will drop the ride height, making the cars handling feel more responsive to driver inputs, but increasing the chance of bottoming out on rougher terrain. 

After changing ride height you must check damper travel and spring compression to ensure theres still sufficient bump and rebound range and no bottoming or topping out.
Re-verify bump stops, ride frequency and alignment settings, and make further adjustments to spring preload or damping as needed so the suspension operates safely and effectively across rally terrain.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>Limited Slip Differential (LSD) preload</> is the initial torque resistance that must be overcome for any speed difference to occur between the two driven wheels on the same axle.

Until this torque threshold is exceeded, both wheels rotate at the same speed, similar to a locked axle. At low lateral accelerations, this preload causes slower corner entry, reduced steering response, and some understeer. However, under high lateral load transfer, it improves traction and stability. 

Preload is especially important on loose surfaces, providing needed traction before the differential fully locks. Front differentials typically require less preload to preserve steering feel.
Description.LocalizedString:
The <StyleBold>Limited Slip Differential (LSD) preload</> is the initial torque resistance that must be overcome for any speed difference to occur between the two driven wheels on the same axle.

Until this torque threshold is exceeded, both wheels rotate at the same speed, similar to a locked axle. At low lateral accelerations, this preload causes slower corner entry, reduced steering response, and some understeer. However, under high lateral load transfer, it improves traction and stability. 

Preload is especially important on loose surfaces, providing needed traction before the differential fully locks. Front differentials typically require less preload to preserve steering feel.

Description.SourceString:
Adjust <StyleBold>tyre pressures</> to maintain the optimal contact patch and working temperature of the tyres.

<StyleBold>Increasing</> tyre pressures increases the stiffness of the tyres sidewall, decreasing the amount of heat produced in the tyre preventing and/or reducing overheating. It does, however, also reduce the tyres contact patch with the road surface, which can decrease grip. 

<StyleBold>Reducing</> tyre pressure increases the tyres contact patch and improves grip, but it does also increase rolling resistance. Lower tyre pressures also allow the tyre to move around and flex more, raising tyre temperatures, but it can increase the risk of the tyre coming off the rim.

Try balancing tyre pressure to keep, for as long as possible, the tyres in their ideal temperature window for maximum grip and durability.
Description.LocalizedString:
Adjust <StyleBold>tyre pressures</> to maintain the optimal contact patch and working temperature of the tyres.

<StyleBold>Increasing</> tyre pressures increases the stiffness of the tyres sidewall, decreasing the amount of heat produced in the tyre preventing and/or reducing overheating. It does, however, also reduce the tyres contact patch with the road surface, which can decrease grip. 

<StyleBold>Reducing</> tyre pressure increases the tyres contact patch and improves grip, but it does also increase rolling resistance. Lower tyre pressures also allow the tyre to move around and flex more, raising tyre temperatures, but it can increase the risk of the tyre coming off the rim.

Try balancing tyre pressure to keep, for as long as possible, the tyres in their ideal temperature window for maximum grip and durability.

Description.SourceString:
In many cars, the <StyleBold>ride height</> is adjusted using a push/pull-rod mechanism. This setup includes a rod connecting the coil over damper to the wheel assembly.

By changing the length of this rod, you can fine-tune the ride height without altering the dampers working position. This means the damping characteristics remain consistent, eliminating the need for further adjustments after ride height changes.

Increase the Rod Length to raise the ride height of the car, preventing the car from bottoming out on rougher more bumpier surfaces, whilst decreasing the Rod Length will lower the ride height. 

This method provides precise control over vehicle stance and suspension geometry, essential for optimizing handling and performance on varied surfaces typical in rally racing.
Description.LocalizedString:
In many cars, the <StyleBold>ride height</> is adjusted using a push/pull-rod mechanism. This setup includes a rod connecting the coil over damper to the wheel assembly.

By changing the length of this rod, you can fine-tune the ride height without altering the dampers working position. This means the damping characteristics remain consistent, eliminating the need for further adjustments after ride height changes.

Increase the Rod Length to raise the ride height of the car, preventing the car from bottoming out on rougher more bumpier surfaces, whilst decreasing the Rod Length will lower the ride height. 

This method provides precise control over vehicle stance and suspension geometry, essential for optimizing handling and performance on varied surfaces typical in rally racing.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>Main Spring</> determines the natural frequency of a car's suspension system, impacting how the car responds to driver input and absorbtion of bumps from the terrain. It also affects wheel droop, reducing rebound if too stiff, causing frequent loss of wheel contact and spring oscillations that may damage the suspension.

This is where Helper Springs and Rebound Stops become crucial, preventing damage by managing suspension travel.

Generally, a higher rear spring frequency is preferred to help the rear wheels better synchronize with the front wheels over bumps, improving stability.

Increasing front spring stiffness tends to increase understeer, while softer front springs promote oversteer. The opposite happens for the rear, where increasing rear springs tends to increase oversteer, while softer rear springs brings the rears balance back towards understeer. Tune the two to find yours and the cars ideal handling balance.
Description.LocalizedString:
The <StyleBold>Main Spring</> determines the natural frequency of a car's suspension system, impacting how the car responds to driver input and absorbtion of bumps from the terrain. It also affects wheel droop, reducing rebound if too stiff, causing frequent loss of wheel contact and spring oscillations that may damage the suspension.

This is where Helper Springs and Rebound Stops become crucial, preventing damage by managing suspension travel.

Generally, a higher rear spring frequency is preferred to help the rear wheels better synchronize with the front wheels over bumps, improving stability.

Increasing front spring stiffness tends to increase understeer, while softer front springs promote oversteer. The opposite happens for the rear, where increasing rear springs tends to increase oversteer, while softer rear springs brings the rears balance back towards understeer. Tune the two to find yours and the cars ideal handling balance.

Description.SourceString:
<StyleBold>Anti-roll bars</> connect the wheels on the same axle to reduce body roll during cornering.
While this decreases roll and helps maintain better camber angles, it also increases load transfer between the tyres, which can reduce the overall grip of that axle.

Raising the anti-roll bar stiffness at the front generally moves the bias towards understeer. Increasing it at the rear tends to cause oversteer by allowing the rear to rotate more in the mid corner.

In rally cars, especially on loose surfaces with long suspension travel, its important to balance anti-roll bar settings. Too much stiffness causes excessive load transfer and tyre grip saturation, while too little roll can lead to poor camber control.
Description.LocalizedString:
<StyleBold>Anti-roll bars</> connect the wheels on the same axle to reduce body roll during cornering.
While this decreases roll and helps maintain better camber angles, it also increases load transfer between the tyres, which can reduce the overall grip of that axle.

Raising the anti-roll bar stiffness at the front generally moves the bias towards understeer. Increasing it at the rear tends to cause oversteer by allowing the rear to rotate more in the mid corner.

In rally cars, especially on loose surfaces with long suspension travel, its important to balance anti-roll bar settings. Too much stiffness causes excessive load transfer and tyre grip saturation, while too little roll can lead to poor camber control.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>handbrake system</> can be finely tuned by adjusting or replacing components such as the handbrake calipers, brake pads, or the master cylinder pressure. With Handbrake Force, you are adjusting the whole system to increase or reduce its effect.

Increasing the Handbrake Force requires less pull on the handbrake to lock the wheels, even on smoother and grippier surfaces, making it easier to rotate the car with less modulation required.

Decreasing the Handbrake Force will require more pull on the handbrake to lock the wheels, reducing the cars desire to rotate as quickly or sharply when trying to engage or modulate the handbrake. 

Tune based on the your preference and the amount of available grip.
Description.LocalizedString:
The <StyleBold>handbrake system</> can be finely tuned by adjusting or replacing components such as the handbrake calipers, brake pads, or the master cylinder pressure. With Handbrake Force, you are adjusting the whole system to increase or reduce its effect.

Increasing the Handbrake Force requires less pull on the handbrake to lock the wheels, even on smoother and grippier surfaces, making it easier to rotate the car with less modulation required.

Decreasing the Handbrake Force will require more pull on the handbrake to lock the wheels, reducing the cars desire to rotate as quickly or sharply when trying to engage or modulate the handbrake. 

Tune based on the your preference and the amount of available grip.

Description.SourceString:
<StyleBold>Front Torque Distribution</> in a 4WD rally car refers to the static distribution of torque sent to the front axle. This setting can be adjusted depending on the drivers style and the surface conditions.

A higher front torque bias generally improves stability and grip on tarmac or solid surfaces, giving the car more predictable handling. Too much bias though can make the car understeer when on throttle and exiting corners.

Shifting the torque bias rearwards is more ideal on loose or slippery surfaces like gravel, where the lower grip levels require more oversteer and rotation to help with cornering. 

However, too much torque toward the rear on loose surfaces often results in reduced control and slower stage times, making it essential to balance torque distribution carefully for optimal performance.
Description.LocalizedString:
<StyleBold>Front Torque Distribution</> in a 4WD rally car refers to the static distribution of torque sent to the front axle. This setting can be adjusted depending on the drivers style and the surface conditions.

A higher front torque bias generally improves stability and grip on tarmac or solid surfaces, giving the car more predictable handling. Too much bias though can make the car understeer when on throttle and exiting corners.

Shifting the torque bias rearwards is more ideal on loose or slippery surfaces like gravel, where the lower grip levels require more oversteer and rotation to help with cornering. 

However, too much torque toward the rear on loose surfaces often results in reduced control and slower stage times, making it essential to balance torque distribution carefully for optimal performance.

Description.SourceString:
In this section, you can adjust the transmission gearing and the final gear ratio of the gearbox.
The overall speed or that of individual gears should be tailored to the specific demands of the track.
It is important to remember that additional adjustments to the differential ratios are available in the dedicated section.
Description.LocalizedString:
In this section, you can adjust the transmission gearing and the final gear ratio of the gearbox.
The overall speed or that of individual gears should be tailored to the specific demands of the track.
It is important to remember that additional adjustments to the differential ratios are available in the dedicated section.

Description.SourceString:
Without proper grip on the surface, it is impossible to fully harness the engines power.
Suspension adjustments allow you to improve the vehicles response according to the driving style and the type of surface.
In the suspension settings area, you can find the main adjustments that help balance the car mechanically. 
By using all available settings, it is possible to achieve the best performance from the vehicle. The goal is to closely follow the road profile while keeping the chassis variations as minimal as possible. 
Softer setups are preferable on rougher terrain, while stiffer setups work better on smoother surfaces.
Description.LocalizedString:
Without proper grip on the surface, it is impossible to fully harness the engines power.
Suspension adjustments allow you to improve the vehicles response according to the driving style and the type of surface.
In the suspension settings area, you can find the main adjustments that help balance the car mechanically. 
By using all available settings, it is possible to achieve the best performance from the vehicle. The goal is to closely follow the road profile while keeping the chassis variations as minimal as possible. 
Softer setups are preferable on rougher terrain, while stiffer setups work better on smoother surfaces.

Description.SourceString:
The adjustment of the dampers allows control over the car's behavior during transients, meaning the moments when load transfers occur.
By exploiting all the adjustment options available on the shock absorbers, it is possible to find the best setup suited to your driving style and the specific stage conditions.
It is important to remember that shock absorbers should not be used for mechanical balancing; that role is fulfilled by the suspension springs and anti-roll bars.
Instead, dumpers must be tuned to match the damping to the suspension stiffness.
Description.LocalizedString:
The adjustment of the dampers allows control over the car's behavior during transients, meaning the moments when load transfers occur.
By exploiting all the adjustment options available on the shock absorbers, it is possible to find the best setup suited to your driving style and the specific stage conditions.
It is important to remember that shock absorbers should not be used for mechanical balancing; that role is fulfilled by the suspension springs and anti-roll bars.
Instead, dumpers must be tuned to match the damping to the suspension stiffness.

Description.SourceString:
In the Axles section, you can adjust the stiffness and damping of any third elements, but most importantly, set the anti-roll bars.
These are the simplest way to quickly change the mechanical balance of the car without worrying about ride height or shock absorber travel.
It is important to remember that, as with suspensions, rougher terrains require lower stiffness so that the wheels can more effectively follow the contours of the surface.

Description.SourceString:
In this section, you can adjust the wheel angles, tyre pressure, and other settings related to wheels and steering, such as the steering ratio or power steering assistance.
These adjustments allow you to optimize tyre grip according to the type of surface you will be driving on.
Description.LocalizedString:

These adjustments allow you to optimize tyre grip according to the type of surface you will be driving on.

Description.SourceString:
Brake control is essential to maintain the right speed in corners: an efficient braking system is the key to achieving excellent performance.
It is crucial to pay close attention to every component of the car's braking system. You can select the brake discs, considering not only their diameter but also their width and type of ventilation.
It is necessary to check which calipers are compatible with the chosen discs and finally choose the proper compound for the brake pads.
Additionally, the brake master cylinder settings can be adjusted to quickly modify the brake balance and braking power.

It is necessary to check which calipers are compatible with the chosen discs and finally choose the proper compound for the brake pads.
Additionally, the brake master cylinder settings can be adjusted to quickly modify the brake balance and braking power.

Description.SourceString:
The differential settings are among the most important and at the same time most complex aspects in tuning a rally car, as they significantly affect the vehicle's behavior.
Therefore, it is advisable to make gradual adjustments in order to fully understand the impact of each setting on driving.
Always adapt the settings according to the type of terrain you are facing.
Description.LocalizedString:
The differential settings are among the most important and at the same time most complex aspects in tuning a rally car, as they significantly affect the vehicle's behavior.
Therefore, it is advisable to make gradual adjustments in order to fully understand the impact of each setting on driving.
Always adapt the settings according to the type of terrain you are facing.

Description.SourceString:
A <StyleBold>limited-slip differential (LSD)</> in a rally car uses <StyleBold>friction plates</> to control torque distribution between the wheels. The number of friction plates in contact directly affects the locking force of the differential, influencing wheel slip in both coast and on-power situations.

<StyleBold>Increasing</> the number of plates amplifies the locking effect, making the LSD more aggressive by transmitting more torque to the wheel with better traction. This can shift the bias towards more stability through more understeer when coasting, but more oversteer when on power.

<StyleBold>Reducing</> the number of plates reduces the locking effect, allowing for freer wheel rotation. This shifts the bias towards more freer rotation and better cornering during coast, but more understeer when on power.

This adjustability enables fine-tuning of the LSD to match driving style and conditions, enhancing traction and vehicle control within various scenarios.
Description.LocalizedString:
A <StyleBold>limited-slip differential (LSD)</> in a rally car uses <StyleBold>friction plates</> to control torque distribution between the wheels. The number of friction plates in contact directly affects the locking force of the differential, influencing wheel slip in both coast and on-power situations.

<StyleBold>Increasing</> the number of plates amplifies the locking effect, making the LSD more aggressive by transmitting more torque to the wheel with better traction. This can shift the bias towards more stability through more understeer when coasting, but more oversteer when on power.

<StyleBold>Reducing</> the number of plates reduces the locking effect, allowing for freer wheel rotation. This shifts the bias towards more freer rotation and better cornering during coast, but more understeer when on power.

This adjustability enables fine-tuning of the LSD to match driving style and conditions, enhancing traction and vehicle control within various scenarios.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>ABS (Anti-lock Braking System)</> is an active safety system that prevents the wheels from locking during sudden braking, thus avoiding skidding and loss of grip.

When the ABS detects locking, it acts cyclically (hundreds of times per second) temporarily reducing the brake pressure on the wheel about to lock. Once the wheel starts to rotate again, the brake pressure is restored.

When the ABS is <StyleBold>deactivated (OFF)</> the control of the brake pressure is completely in the hands of the driver. As the <StyleBold>ABS values increase</>, the system becomes more sensitive to the pressure, anticipating the wheel lock and optimizing the response.

The braking distance with the ABS active may be slightly longer than with a driver-controlled braking without locking the wheels. However, in the event of a wheel lock, stopping times are significantly longer without ABS.
On slippery surfaces, such as dirt and snow, the ABS may be too intrusive due to the ease with which the wheels lock.
Description.LocalizedString:
The <StyleBold>ABS (Anti-lock Braking System)</> is an active safety system that prevents the wheels from locking during sudden braking, thus avoiding skidding and loss of grip.

When the ABS detects locking, it acts cyclically (hundreds of times per second) temporarily reducing the brake pressure on the wheel about to lock. Once the wheel starts to rotate again, the brake pressure is restored.

When the ABS is <StyleBold>deactivated (OFF)</> the control of the brake pressure is completely in the hands of the driver. As the <StyleBold>ABS values increase</>, the system becomes more sensitive to the pressure, anticipating the wheel lock and optimizing the response.

The braking distance with the ABS active may be slightly longer than with a driver-controlled braking without locking the wheels. However, in the event of a wheel lock, stopping times are significantly longer without ABS.
On slippery surfaces, such as dirt and snow, the ABS may be too intrusive due to the ease with which the wheels lock.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>TCS (Traction Control System)</> is a traction control system that prevents the drive wheels from slipping during acceleration by reducing engine power or intervening on the brakes when it detects that one wheel is spinning faster than the others.

The system optimizes the performance and stability of the vehicle, especially during acceleration in difficult conditions such as rain, snow or slippery surfaces. Furthermore, by reducing wheel slippage during extreme acceleration, it improves traction and ensures more efficient power transfer.

With the <StyleBold>TCS deactivated (OFF)</> the driver has full control over acceleration. Greater experience is required in dosing the pressure, preventing loss of grip and thus obtaining superior performance.

By <StyleBold>increasing the intensity</> of the system, the TCS becomes more sensitive to wheel slippage, intervening to reduce it and ensuring adequate performance even for those with less experience, reducing the need to carefully control the accelerator.
Description.LocalizedString:
The <StyleBold>TCS (Traction Control System)</> is a traction control system that prevents the drive wheels from slipping during acceleration by reducing engine power or intervening on the brakes when it detects that one wheel is spinning faster than the others.

The system optimizes the performance and stability of the vehicle, especially during acceleration in difficult conditions such as rain, snow or slippery surfaces. Furthermore, by reducing wheel slippage during extreme acceleration, it improves traction and ensures more efficient power transfer.

With the <StyleBold>TCS deactivated (OFF)</> the driver has full control over acceleration. Greater experience is required in dosing the pressure, preventing loss of grip and thus obtaining superior performance.

By <StyleBold>increasing the intensity</> of the system, the TCS becomes more sensitive to wheel slippage, intervening to reduce it and ensuring adequate performance even for those with less experience, reducing the need to carefully control the accelerator.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>Engine Map</> controls how torque is delivered to the wheels. Different maps adjust engine performance to suit varying driving conditions, optimizing power output and responsiveness.

<StyleBold>Lower maps</> prioritize maximum torque from lower rpms for aggressive acceleration on smooth surfaces, while <StyleBold>higher maps</> offer smoother, more controlled power delivery with high rpms powerband for looser surfaces.

By switching between these maps, drivers can adapt to terrain changes, enhancing traction, stability, and overall vehicle control.
Description.LocalizedString:
The <StyleBold>Engine Map</> controls how torque is delivered to the wheels. Different maps adjust engine performance to suit varying driving conditions, optimizing power output and responsiveness.

<StyleBold>Lower maps</> prioritize maximum torque from lower rpms for aggressive acceleration on smooth surfaces, while <StyleBold>higher maps</> offer smoother, more controlled power delivery with high rpms powerband for looser surfaces.

By switching between these maps, drivers can adapt to terrain changes, enhancing traction, stability, and overall vehicle control.

Description.SourceString:
The <StyleBold>Throttle Map</> controls how the engine responds to accelerator input, adjusting throttle sensitivity to suit different driving conditions.

Varying throttle maps allow the driver to select the ideal response for traction and control, whether on loose gravel, tarmac, or slippery surfaces.

A <StyleBold>more sensitive map</> delivers quicker engine response for aggressive driving, while a <StyleBold>gentler map</> provides smoother, more manageable power delivery to prevent wheel spin.

This adaptability helps optimize performance and stability, giving the driver better control and confidence across diverse rally stages with changing terrain and grip levels.
